Situation1: They make weekly phone calls to update their parents on life events and ask about their well-being.
Situation2: They must follow strict procedures for a large cash deposit at the end of a busy shift to comply with corporate auditing rules.
Story: The clock above the register blinked 8:55 p.m. as I counted the bills, my hands stiff from a long shift. The store was nearly empty, and I still had to finish the deposit paperwork before closing. My phone buzzed in my pocket—Mom’s name lit up the screen. It was our weekly call, the one she always said made her feel like I was really part of the family. I knew she’d be waiting, probably sitting with Dad, hoping to hear about my week, asking if I was eating well, if I was happy. But the deposit had to be perfect; the manager warned us that any mistake could mean a write-up or worse. I felt the pressure of the store’s rules pressing down on me, but also the weight of Mom’s gentle expectation, her need for connection. My heart pounded as I stared at the phone, torn between the family I was trying to belong to and the job I couldn’t afford to lose.
